Answer: By specifically mentioning petrol and diesel, I assume you are talking about creating alternative fuels for transportation, rather than simply talking about petroleum by-products such as plastics.The answer, as others have stated, is that we can do that today, although it will cost you in terms of energy required (and thus cost). It has been proposed that for manned Mars missions that methane-based rocket fuel be robotically produced on Mars using CO2 and water present on the planet. This fuel could then be used for the return trip(s).Here is a recent development in this technology:By specifically mentioning petrol and diesel, I assume you are talking about creating alternative fuels for transportation, rather than simply talking about petroleum by-products such as plastics.The answer, as others have stated, is that we can do that today, although it will cost you in terms of energy required (and thus cost). It has been proposed that for manned Mars missions that methane-based rocket fuel be robotically produced on Mars using CO2 and water present on the planet. This fuel could then be used for the return trip(s).Here is a recent development in this technology:But I guess my question back to you would be: why do we need to expend a great amount of energy to produce liquid (or gaseous) fuels that we’re just going to burn after a single use, when we have clearly superior solutions today (batteries and electric motors) that can far more efficiently just use the energy you would use to produce to petrol and diesel (or methane/natural gas) to go MUCH farther?

question: https://www.quora.com/When-petrol-and-diesel-were-extinct-can-we-create-it-in-the-future-with-our-advanced-technology

Answer: A first process of synthetic fuel has been developed in France in 1920’s from coal (lignite) liquefaction but it was too expensive. Then 2 german chimistes, Fisher and Tropsch, developed a synthetic fuel in liquefying a synthetic gas made from coal. Then a third German, Bergius, developed at the beginning of WWII the direct liquefaction with hydrogen and coal and tars at a temperature of 450 °C, with a 200 atmosphères pressure, with a catalyst.You maybe have heard that recently Germany decided to iA first process of synthetic fuel has been developed in France in 1920’s from coal (lignite) liquefaction but it was too expensive. Then 2 german chimistes, Fisher and Tropsch, developed a synthetic fuel in liquefying a synthetic gas made from coal. Then a third German, Bergius, developed at the beginning of WWII the direct liquefaction with hydrogen and coal and tars at a temperature of 450 °C, with a 200 atmosphères pressure, with a catalyst.You maybe have heard that recently Germany decided to invest massively into « green hydrogen » to lead this market.Today hydrogen is made from methane but produces CO2 as well. Green H2 will be made from water electrolysis. It will be a way to store the excess energy coming from solar and wind energy. (Tesla plans to store it in batteries)Green H2 will be used for industry and heavy transportationBut when you combine green hydrogen with ambient CO2, you can create a synthetic fuel. This way you remove some CO2 from the air, create a clean fuel (less particles, no sulfur’s and tars,…) that would be far better for sea freight.This is not advanced technology, we just need the motivation to move to a cleaner use of energy by any government. And that’s what Germany just decided to do.

Answer: Even assuming that EVERY main car manufacturer started building E.V.s RIGHT NOW, that where 100% Suitable for every use currently on the road, it would take AT LEAST 20 years to replace the current fleet, if you FORCED everyone to buy electric.Now, that is of course not going to happen.Firstly, Battery tech is not good enough to replace every vehicle on the road, though it IS getting better. However even those batteries that ARE available are just to expensive. Which makes the car MORE expensive. And people less likely to change.Secondly, There is just not enough batteries being manufactured,Even assuming that EVERY main car manufacturer started building E.V.s RIGHT NOW, that where 100% Suitable for every use currently on the road, it would take AT LEAST 20 years to replace the current fleet, if you FORCED everyone to buy electric.Now, that is of course not going to happen.Firstly, Battery tech is not good enough to replace every vehicle on the road, though it IS getting better. However even those batteries that ARE available are just to expensive. Which makes the car MORE expensive. And people less likely to change.Secondly, There is just not enough batteries being manufactured, or for that matter materials being mined FOR those batteries right now. Obviously more manufacturing facilities are opening as demand increases, like wise more mines. But its a slow process, and takes time. This limits the amount of E.V.s that can be manufactured.Third. Even once we CAN start manufacturing more E.V.s, not everyone can afford a new car. There will be a significant delay before CHEAP second hand E.V.s come on the market in any significant number. And we really don't know how those vehicles will perform, or what problems they will have. Manufacturers like Tesla, CLAIM 1,000,000 miles, but we don't know how correct that is, and many of these cars will still have the same problems as normal I.C.E. cars. Switches and electronics wear out, paint scratches, Inside Styling become unpopular, or just plane worn. Replacement parts become unavailable.Another interesting dilemma, many of these cars rely heavily on computers. As the last twenty years has shown us, computer tech evolves VERY quickly. It’s quite likely that even ten year old computer tech in E.V.s, will just not be sufficiently updateable software wise anymore.Even WHEN we can start manufacturing enough cars of the correct variety of models and types to replace the current fleet at a reasonable cost, it’s going to take at least twenty years to phase out “most” I.C.E.My guess is, unless there is a SERIOUS push from green politics to FORCE People to change to E.V.s we will still be seeing I.C.E. vehicles on the roads for at least another 30 years. And probably even after that.Even then there are bound to be some diehards who just can’t let their I.C.E. vehicles go. I know I will miss the beautiful sound of a nicely engineered V8, and the artistry that can go into making a truly well engineered automobile.And lets not even get started on how we are going to replace a “V” twin Harley…

Answer: Thank you for the A2A (as it is, from Tomurcuk Yelman).The question:Can a modern day scientist not believe in evolution?Evolution is not my field of study, but I think I can say this:For a scientist in that field, it is not a matter of belief in this or that, but rather one of coming to conclude on rational grounds that evolution is a fact. To speak of his or her “belief in evolution,” then, is to assimilate science to religion in a grossly distorted way, very unfair to science.Setting that aside …Given the complex structure of the human brain, which features components that date from differenThank you for the A2A (as it is, from Tomurcuk Yelman).The question:Can a modern day scientist not believe in evolution?Evolution is not my field of study, but I think I can say this:For a scientist in that field, it is not a matter of belief in this or that, but rather one of coming to conclude on rational grounds that evolution is a fact. To speak of his or her “belief in evolution,” then, is to assimilate science to religion in a grossly distorted way, very unfair to science.Setting that aside …Given the complex structure of the human brain, which features components that date from different eons, and the fact that it is so very delicate in its operations and prone to error on the level of the individual, if not on that of society as a whole through the centuries, and the fact of human variability, it would not be so very surprising to come across an intelligent, knowledgeable historian who is convinced, due to his membership in a peculiar religious cult, that he lived in ancient Akkad in a previous life and invented cuneiform script, or another person, a knowledgeable biologist, perhaps, convinced, due to her membership in another peculiar cult, Christianity, perhaps, that evolution is a sham.But what of it? Oddities like these reflect the nature of the human brain, not that of the great, wide reality that it seeks to comprehend.

question: https://www.quora.com/When-petrol-and-diesel-were-extinct-can-we-create-it-in-the-future-with-our-advanced-technology

Answer: Long but interesting story-I went to an Amish sawmill once to discuss placing an order for wooden pallets. The owner was there but his son handled the business end and he would not be back for an hour so I waited. I was having a pleasant conversation about the usual things- how the weather was, how the crops were doing this year, etc and all. During the course of our discussion somehow it came out that I was a mechanic and he had a broken diesel air compressor, so we moved into the building and while I was looking at his compressor (which powered all his shop equipment) I asked him to explainLong but interesting story-I went to an Amish sawmill once to discuss placing an order for wooden pallets. The owner was there but his son handled the business end and he would not be back for an hour so I waited. I was having a pleasant conversation about the usual things- how the weather was, how the crops were doing this year, etc and all. During the course of our discussion somehow it came out that I was a mechanic and he had a broken diesel air compressor, so we moved into the building and while I was looking at his compressor (which powered all his shop equipment) I asked him to explain to me the philosophy regarding the Amish and electricity.His answer was that electricity was not “bad” or “evil” in any sort of way, but that it was for the most part “unnecessary” for most important things in life and the one certainty is that once allowed in where do you draw the line as to what is necessary and what is not? He used electric lights as an example, it is easy to install them and then have light whenever and wherever you need it, but then you wind up subconsciously doing thing you should have done during daylight that you can now do later on and as a result your life can gradually change without you being completely aware of that happening and without being completely aware perhaps it is changing in a way that is not in your best interest and well being. So for many it is their choice to not allow electricity into their household even if many of them now have electrified places of business.Anyway, that is my interpretation of my discussion with one Amish business owner and in no way did I ever get the feeling that technology was something they “feared”, most simply believe there are more important things in life that modern technology has a tendency to usurp given the opportunity.I got his compressor fixed, his son showed up (on a tractor) and we talked business for a bit and before I left the Dad picked a bunch of sweet corn for me in exchange for fixing the compressor, which I thanked him for.

Answer: Not unless it was more than 500 million years ago (therefore aliens).The reason is mundane:Strip miningOur civilization is such because we’re extremely efficient at extracting natural resources from soil. We take down entire mountains for what hides beneath, we dig deep and extract whatever of value it is down below for us to extract.A civilization at our technological level would also do so, because it needs those resources to sustain itself. A different such civilization within the last 500 million years would leave very little easily available resources for us to extract.If it’s longer thanNot unless it was more than 500 million years ago (therefore aliens).The reason is mundane:Strip miningOur civilization is such because we’re extremely efficient at extracting natural resources from soil. We take down entire mountains for what hides beneath, we dig deep and extract whatever of value it is down below for us to extract.A civilization at our technological level would also do so, because it needs those resources to sustain itself. A different such civilization within the last 500 million years would leave very little easily available resources for us to extract.If it’s longer than about 500 million years, then those resources would have had time to reform back in the soil. The line is a tad arbitrary, but accurate within one digit.

Answer: This is Earth OKThis is the solar system in which Earth resides. We are surrounded by several other planets and orbit a star we call the sun.Further out in space, there are several solar systems surrounding ours forming what we call the Solar Interstellar Neighborhood. Each of these solar systems contains stars and planets.See that tiny, tiny dot? So tiny you can’t even see it? That is our Solar Interstellar System. From here, we can’t even make out our solar system let alone individual planets. The galaxy is enormous. We are rotating what is believed to be a black hole. Current scientific estThis is Earth OKThis is the solar system in which Earth resides. We are surrounded by several other planets and orbit a star we call the sun.Further out in space, there are several solar systems surrounding ours forming what we call the Solar Interstellar Neighborhood. Each of these solar systems contains stars and planets.See that tiny, tiny dot? So tiny you can’t even see it? That is our Solar Interstellar System. From here, we can’t even make out our solar system let alone individual planets. The galaxy is enormous. We are rotating what is believed to be a black hole. Current scientific estimates conclude that there are approximately 100 billion stars in our galaxy alone with planets orbiting them.As we travel further into space, the entire galaxy becomes just a dot of light. Each of those other dots are other galaxies.Further away, it is possible to see the Virgo Supercluster. That red notation represents our local galactic group, containing all of the galaxies near us. In that is the Milky Way galaxy. In that is the solar interstellar neighborhood. In that is our solar system. In that is planet Earth.The local supercluster group contains the virgo supercluster, where we are located, as well as the other superclusters near us.That tiny dot that you can hardly make out on the screen is the Virgo Supercluster. All of those other dots are superclusters. And this is just the observable universe that we can estimate. It is believed that there are countless, perhaps even infinite, other dimensions. Theoretically, planet Earth could have entire civilizations that exist in other dimensions we can’t access or interact with at the present time. Then there is the issue of time and gravity. If time travel is possible, all of these universes would be occurring at the same time everywhere in all dimensions.Multiverse?The multiverse is a hypothetical group of multiple universes.Together, these universes comprise everything that exists: the entirety of space, time, matter, energy, information, and the physical laws and constants that describe them.Do you still think we are alone in the Universe?

Answer: Gaze on this.That is an image of a child suffering from Hutchinson-Gilford progeria. A single mutation in just one gene - the LMNA gene - means an abnormal, misshapen version of a protein named lamin A is produced. The altered protein makes the nuclear envelope - the lamina - unstable and progressively damages the nucleus, meaning cells die prematurely. It's much more complex than that, but essentially HG progeria kills the child through a slow, agonising process of premature aging. By the time the poor, doomed child is eight their body is racked with arthritis, cardiac problems, cataracts, loGaze on this.That is an image of a child suffering from Hutchinson-Gilford progeria. A single mutation in just one gene - the LMNA gene - means an abnormal, misshapen version of a protein named lamin A is produced. The altered protein makes the nuclear envelope - the lamina - unstable and progressively damages the nucleus, meaning cells die prematurely. It's much more complex than that, but essentially HG progeria kills the child through a slow, agonising process of premature aging. By the time the poor, doomed child is eight their body is racked with arthritis, cardiac problems, cataracts, loss of hair and teeth and so on - all the problems we associate with extreme old age. Survival past the late teens is almost unheard of. There is no cure and little hope of one, though therapies developed using CRISPR CaS9 look very promising. For the forseeable future, though, there is no relief, no respite, no reprieve. Progeria is 100% fatal.I will spare you the images of children suffering from Harlequin ichthyosis. Google them for yourselves, but don’t say I didn’t warn you. Again, this is an inherited disease, caused by a single point mutation in the ABCA12 gene.Now, these horrendous syndromes are easy to understand from an accident-prone molecule like DNA. It has no more human feeling than the vinegar you pour on your chips. It doesn't know, it doesn't think, it doesn't feel or care. It justI cannot, however, understand why a caring, loving, all-seeing, all-knowing God needed to include in his Universe a method of torturing children to death.Why?If someone can explain to me why this wizard with the big beard who lives in the sky likes to make pretty rainbows while watching children writhing in pain before he drags the life out of them, I'll be happy to listen.I'll laugh in their face, they won't convince me, but I will still listen.EDIT : Argue as much as you like but any comments that rely on childish personal insults to try to make a point - regardless of the merits of that point - will be deleted, as will comments by anti vaccination conspiracy whackjobs. This applies equally to theists, atheists or anyone in between. Please also bear in mind that contributors are free to delete their own comments and often do, presumably after rereading them and realising that they made themselves look like semi-literate dimwits.

Answer: You seem sincere.Many of us started out as believers. Then for whatever reason we had some questions because the world as traditionally described by Abrahamic religion didn’t seem to correspond to what we were noticing.The question that comes up again and again is this one: you have this god with unlimited powers, who knows everything, and who is all-good, so why is there so much suffering in the world?Inevitably when you ask a version of this question, your religious elders will give you answers that sound like they’re making up excuses. Or they will shut you down by telling you not to ask suYou seem sincere.Many of us started out as believers. Then for whatever reason we had some questions because the world as traditionally described by Abrahamic religion didn’t seem to correspond to what we were noticing.The question that comes up again and again is this one: you have this god with unlimited powers, who knows everything, and who is all-good, so why is there so much suffering in the world?Inevitably when you ask a version of this question, your religious elders will give you answers that sound like they’re making up excuses. Or they will shut you down by telling you not to ask such questions.But the questions don’t go away. You’re left still wondering. Then you learn about evolution and you think: that makes sense! And you learn about religious myths from other cultures and you think: hmm, that’s kind of like what I grew up believing. Then slowly the weird stories from your religion stop making sense.You cross out the talking snakes and the walking on water and the flying horses, etc.Okay, you think, now I have a good religion without all the hard-to-believe stuff.Then you dig deeper and you realize that even the “good” parts have problems: xenophobia, sexism, slavery, exhortations to kill people who offend your faith or to go to war against them.That makes you uncomfortable.You decide you need a break from religion to think things through.You meditate and cogitate and wonder and ponder and you decide that you just can’t adhere to organized religion. You’re going to believe in your god but you can’t in good conscience be part of a religion whose texts advocate actions you consider morally abhorrent.Then you hear people talk of God. Every time they give arguments for his existence, it sounds hollow.Slowly, you start to realize that you just don’t think there is a god. This frightens you at first because you’ve been raised to think that atheists are immoral. But when you try to believe you just can’t shake the feeling that you have no more evidence for the god you believe in than the ancient Egyptians and Greeks did about their many gods. You come to view gods as nothing more than the expression and translation of our hopes into mythological form and the ever-shrinking total sum of what we do not yet understand.That’s why many of us don’t believe. We’ve read the books and heard the sermons and attended the religious services and participated in the rituals and sung the songs. But we also studied the history and exposed our minds to more than just the internal logic of the religion we happen to be born into. And once you’ve opened those doors, it’s almost impossible to close them again.

Answer: Loudly and firmly - both. Quantum physics started as a purely intellectual exercise, a desire to understand the world. But it is now deeply embedded in highly profitable products. Particularly, as others have said, the semiconductor industry, and the communications industry. Without it, we would not have the Internet as we understand it. But equally, it is deeply involved in battery developments which we need if we are to leave off the use of fossil fuels, And, of course, solar cells.Quantum Physics is a classic example where “blue sky” research, carried out through pure intellectual curiosityLoudly and firmly - both. Quantum physics started as a purely intellectual exercise, a desire to understand the world. But it is now deeply embedded in highly profitable products. Particularly, as others have said, the semiconductor industry, and the communications industry. Without it, we would not have the Internet as we understand it. But equally, it is deeply involved in battery developments which we need if we are to leave off the use of fossil fuels, And, of course, solar cells.Quantum Physics is a classic example where “blue sky” research, carried out through pure intellectual curiosity, turned out to have huge commercial importance half a century and more later. It is now just a century since the flurry of developments which shaped quantum mechanics. Probably most of those who participated - Bohr, Schroedinger, Planck, Heisenberg and so on - would never have imagined the vast majority of the applications of their work. Yet they are fundamental to modern industry,

Answer: Quantum mechanics is very useful. It engages atoms and particles. We use it in electronics, radio telescopes, even biology (chlorophyll, retina, biochemical pathways, and perhaps even consciousness).But, more basically, we want to know about reality. The better we understand the infrastructure of our world, and the better technology we have to actually grapple with it and do things with atoms and particles — the more we can advance not only science but also technology, industry, commerce, prosperity and human well-being.Still, quantum is not the most basic level. We are still scratching our heQuantum mechanics is very useful. It engages atoms and particles. We use it in electronics, radio telescopes, even biology (chlorophyll, retina, biochemical pathways, and perhaps even consciousness).But, more basically, we want to know about reality. The better we understand the infrastructure of our world, and the better technology we have to actually grapple with it and do things with atoms and particles — the more we can advance not only science but also technology, industry, commerce, prosperity and human well-being.Still, quantum is not the most basic level. We are still scratching our heads trying to figure out how the physical vacuum itself works, what actually are space, time, energy and matter, where it all came from. We still don’t have a solid Unified Field Theory nor Theory of Everything.Will we ever know completely?
